docs.lead_paragraph: With President Bush and John Kerry set to debate on Thursday, American political journalism is proclaiming that the occasion is a crucial ''test'' for Mr. Kerry, and perhaps for Mr. Bush. Indeed. But it's also a test for journalists. Phony documents and dishonest advertising have captured more attention than the facts of the candidates' competing claims about health care, or whether either has a plan -- a plausible plan -- for Iraq. And neither candidate's acceptance speech got widespread scrutiny.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Adam Clymer says test for journalists in presidential debates will be to summarize and analyze what is said without emphasizing style over substance; says research shows that public's views are influenced by what news media emphasize; says in striving to be evenhanded, to seem fair to both sides, journalists can sometimes forget to be fair to public (M)
docs.snippet: Thursday's debate will be a test of whether the news media can focus on what the candidates actually say.

docs.lead_paragraph: Three years ago, an innovative agreement brought an end to hostilities between the Korean immigrants who ran New York's greengroceries and the thousands of Mexican immigrants who did the groceries' grunt work. The Mexicans picketed many greengrocers, accusing them of violating minimum-wage laws by paying them $250 for 72-hour weeks -- $3.47 an hour, far less than the $5.15 federal minimum -- while the greengrocers asserted that they were the targets of an anti-Korean campaign. Amid fears that the dispute would erupt into violence, the state attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, got the two sides to drop their threats by forging an unusual truce: a code of conduct that 200 of the city's estimated 1,000 greengrocers signed, pledging to comply with minimum-wage and overtime laws and agreeing to inspections.

headline.main: Labor Truce Wearing Thin For Koreans And Mexicans

docs.abstract: Innovative agreement bringing end to hostilities between Korean immigrants who run New York City's greengroceries and Mexican immigrants who work for them expires in February, making some workers concerned about return to lower wages; Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, who brokered deal, and greengrocers are discussing extending agreement, but many merchants would be happy to let it expire because they dislike having their stores inspected by outside monitors; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Three years ago, an innovative agreement brought an end to hostilities between the Korean immigrants who ran New York's greengroceries and the thousands of Mexican immigrants who did the groceries' grunt work.

byline.original: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE and SETH KUGEL

docs.lead_paragraph: Eugene Lee will do whatever it takes to get to the office. Mr. Lee, an account manager at the advertising firm Regan Campbell Ward, went to work with an acute case of food poisoning while at a previous job and spent most of the morning scrambling between his desk and the bathroom. Another time, after spraining his ankle, he hobbled from his home in Queens into the subway and rode into Manhattan so he would not miss a day's work.

headline.main: When Employees Are Sick, Absenteeism Can Be a Virtue

docs.abstract: Employment researchers and employers themselves are increasingly acknowledging that having sick employees stumble to work and slog through day--phenomenon they call 'presenteeism'--is not just painful for employees, but can also hurt company, because ailing workers are unlikely to perform at their normal level and they may also infect others; Journal of Occupational and Environmental Medicine study estimates that productivity losses stemming from presenteeism could be as high as 60 percent of total cost to comp;any of worker illnesses, eclipsing costs of absenteeism and medical and disability benefits; some companies are offering preventive health programs; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Employment researchers are increasingly acknowledging that having sick employees work is not just painful for the employees, but can also hurt the company.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: JOURNAL OF OCCUPATIONAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL MEDICINE

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL 3-23 Iraqi Guard Applicants Killed Seven Iraqi men applying for jobs with the Iraqi National Guard were ambushed and killed in western Baghdad, while the United States military said four marines and a soldier had been killed over 24 hours. Meanwhile, the military said it had conducted an airstrike in Falluja to kill militants holding a meeting. 8 North Korea Talks in Doubt Multinational talks about North Korea's nuclear facilities did not resume, putting the future of the talks in doubt. 17 Britain Offers Debt Aid Britain is planning a new effort to help impoverished third world countries reduce their huge debts by offering to pay off 10 percent of the total owed to international agencies and challenging other nations to follow suit, said the Chancellor of the Exchequer. 20 NATIONAL 24-34 4th Hurricane Hits Florida Hurricane Jeanne, a Category 3 storm with winds of 115 miles an hour, struck Florida's east coast. Two million Floridians were urged to evacuate. 24 Roughly 68,000 people in Pensacola remain without electricity and much of the city remains without sewage service more after Hurricane Ivan washed through the city. 24 New Voters in 2 Swing States A voter registration campaign in heavily Democratic areas has added tens of thousands of new voters to the rolls in Ohio and Florida, a surge that has far exceeded Republican efforts, a review of data shows. 1 Guantánamo Trial Challenges Officials acknowledge that the first full war crimes trial before a military tribunal at Guantánamo is in turmoil and say there will be substantial changes made in coming weeks. 29 Corporate Medicare Rivals The new Medicare law, under which Medicare will rely on private health plans, has touched off a battle between insurance companies and drug companies that could determine how many medicines will be available to Medicare beneficiaries. 1 OBITUARIES 44-45 NEW YORK/REGION 37-43 Race Tightens in New Jersey Republicans have succeeded in gaining points in New Jersey, a perennially Democratic state, based on the war on terror. The gains have been made despite disapproval by a majority of its residents of President Bush's performance in office and his stance on the war in Iraq, health care, the economy and gay marriage. 37 4 Die in Fiery Car Wreck Four teenagers celebrating their 17-year-old friend's getting a new driver's license died in a fiery car accident on Long Island when a drunken driver crashed into their Honda sedan, the Nassau County police said. After being hit on its side, the Honda careered into a telephone pole and exploded. 39 Chess 43 Weather 32

docs.lead_paragraph: The Long Beach city manager, who was hired eight months ago after a change in leadership on the City Council, resigned on Monday, indicating that a medical condition required him to retire. The official, Glen L. Spiritis, suffers from multiple sclerosis, said Charles T. Theofan, the city's corporation counsel, who will serve as acting city manager until a permanent successor is found. Mr. Theofan said the city would commence a nationwide search.
docs.abstract: City manager Glen Spiritis of Long Beach, NY, who suffers from multiple sclerosis, resigns, effective November 4; city corporation counsel Charles Theofan is named acting city manager (S)
docs.snippet: The Long Beach city manager, who was hired eight months ago after a change in leadership on the City Council, resigned on Monday, indicating that a medical condition required him to retire.     The official, Glen L. Spiritis, suffers from multiple...

docs.lead_paragraph: TOIVO LAHTI grows papaya on the Big Island of Hawaii. Over the last few years, he watched other growers start planting trees that were genetically engineered to resist a devastating virus. But Mr. Lahti stuck to conventional varieties for his organic orchard, and thought it would remain free of biotechnology, which he opposes. Then, last spring, some of Mr. Lahti's fruit tested positive for genetically modified seeds. ''I was really surprised,'' Mr. Lahti said. ''I didn't really know what was happening.''

headline.main: Ideas & Trends; Can Biotech Crops Be Good Neighbors?

docs.abstract: Spread of pollen or seeds from genetically engineered plants is evolving from abstract scientific worry into significant practical problem; farmers, especially those raising organic crops, worry that they will lose sales from what they call contamination; environmentalists worry that modified genes could escape from crops into weeds, wreaking ecological havoc; Environmental Protection Agency reports that type of creeping bentgrass modified to resist Roundup, popular herbicide, can pollinate conventional grass 13 miles away; that has raised fears that new gene could spread to wild grasses, creating weeds immune to world's most widely used weed-killer; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The spread of pollen or seeds from genetically engineered plants is evolving from an abstract scientific worry into a significant practical problem.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE nation's health care bill is high and headed higher. Yet most hospitals lose money or barely break even. Doctors complain they are getting squeezed. Employers bemoan rising health care costs as a threat to global competitiveness. Then there are people like Dr. Thomas J. Fogarty, whose career is testimony to the entrepreneurial opportunity of high-tech medicine in America. He got his introduction to medicine as an eighth grader when he worked part time at the Good Samaritan Hospital in Cincinnati, cleaning stomach pumps and stacking bedpans. Soon, he was made a scrub technician so he saw a lot of surgery firsthand as teenager.

headline.main: The Nation:  Health Care Costs Are a Killer, but Maybe That's a Plus

docs.abstract: Health care economists say main reason health care spending is rising is that modern medical technology has made it possible to do more for more people; say millions of people are being treated for ailments that went untreated or undetected years ago; say that spells more operations and more pills, and costs pile up; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The technological marvels of medicine mean that the insured majority are being treated for ailments that went untreated or undetected years ago.
docs.section_name: Technology; Science; Health; Week in Review

docs.lead_paragraph: The new Medicare law has touched off a huge battle between insurance companies and drug companies that could determine how many medicines will be readily available to Medicare beneficiaries. Under the law, Medicare will rely on private health plans to deliver drug benefits to the elderly and disabled. The government will not specify precisely which drugs must be covered. Rather, each plan will develop a list of drugs approved for reimbursement.

headline.main: MEDICARE RULES SET OFF A BATTLE ON DRUG CHOICES

docs.abstract: New Medicare law touches off huge battle between insurance companies and drug companies that could determine how many medicines will be readily available to Medicare beneficiaries; under law, private health plans will develop list of drugs approved for reimbursement to Medicare recipients; in general, insurers and drug benefit managers want to limit number of drugs, and types of drugs, on their lists, while drug companies want as many drugs as possible on each private health plan's list; Bush administration has retained private nonprofit organization, United States Pharmacopeia, to develop list of types of drugs that should be covered; guidelines, which serve as model for private plans providing new drug benefit, list 146 distinct categories and classes of drugs; under new law and administration rules, private plans must cover at least two drugs in each category and class; drug lists drawn up by health plans could determine how many people sign up for drug benefits and how many private plans participate; drug companies and patients argue that patients should have access to full array of drugs for major diseases; Sen John Kerry has denounced law as giveaway to insurance and pharmaceutical companies (M)
docs.snippet: A battle between insurers and drug companies could determine how many medicines will be available to beneficiaries.

docs.lead_paragraph: PARENTS of Connecticut college underclassmen looking forward to the various parents weekends this autumn may have an urgent question for the administration when they arrive on campus: Will tuition and fees keep surging? ''The real question is how stiff are they going to be,'' said Travis Reindle, director of state policy analysis at the American Association of State Colleges and Universities.

headline.main: The Price of Admission Is on the Rise

docs.abstract: Article on rise in tuition and fees at Connecticut colleges; University of Connecticut's main campus tuition incrased for in-staters by 7.7 percent, to $7,338; Connecticut State University tuition and fees increased 12.5 percent, to average of $5,760; tuition and fees at private colleges reportedly rose 6 percent, to $23,858; photos (M)
docs.snippet: PARENTS of Connecticut college underclassmen looking forward to the various parents weekends this autumn may have an urgent question for the administration when they arrive on campus: Will tuition and fees keep surging?    ''The real question is how...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration has broken new ground in its ''faith-based'' initiative, this time by offering federal employees a Catholic health plan that specifically excludes payment for contraceptives, abortion, sterilization and artificial insemination. The new plan, announced last week, combines two White House priorities. It is part of a $1 billion project seeking to involve religious organizations in all types of federal social programs. At the same time, the plan is a new form of coverage -- a health savings account combined with high-deductible coverage -- that is being promoted as a centerpiece of President Bush's health care policy.

headline.main: Federal Health Plans to Include One Shaped by Catholic Tenets

docs.abstract: Bush administration offers federal employees Catholic health plan sponsored by OSF Health; plan excludes payment for contraceptives, abortion and other services; is first for federal workers to be marketed as 'faith-based' and is part of $1 billion plan to involve religious organizations in all types of federal social programs; 1984 law prohibits federal plans from covering most abortions, but 1999 law requires plans to cover contraception; 4 million federal employees will have choice of 249 health plans sponsored by dozens of insurers in 2005; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The Bush administration has broken new ground in its "faith-based" initiative by offering federal employees a Catholic health plan.
